ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Wonderful. Buonocore is a fabulous professor. If you're on the fence about which language to take, go with Italian. It's not the absolute easiest, but if you've got a working knowledge of French or Spanish, it's very doable, and by the end of L2 you're conversational and know a hell of a lot of subjunctive tenses. More importantly, it's really fun, and occasionally you get free food. It's a 9:30 a.m. class every single morning, and I still found it fun.

ITAL 120 was a good continuation. It was more comprehensive and less erratic than 110. While the material covered was more difficult, I never had to learn an entire unit in one week like I did in 110, which meant that I was able to learn concepts better and with less stress.
Yes definitely. Despite the fact that it is a lot more challenging than Italian 110, it is extremely rewarding.
Great course! You learn so much more Italian. Fun and existing
On the whole a slower class with more complicated subject matter than ITAL 110, but you get to a level where you actually understand quite a bit of Italian.

ITAL 120 is full of Italian grammar and has plenty of Italian vocabulary in useful areas. I would recommend this to anyone who wants to learn Italian at a reasonable pace and has taken ITAL 110 or has a similar level of Italian language skills.
yes - of any language, i would recommend italian

I would highly recommend Ital 120! It is a hard course, like all language courses at Yale, but it gives you a great foundation in the language and you will be able to speak in a limited capacity with natives by the end of this course.
